title: Granta 2: The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H.
author: Walter Abish
description:
In the second issue of Granta is a novella by George Steiner, short stories by John Barth, Robert Coover, Walter Abish and others, along with essays on contemporary fiction and poetry.

CONTENTS:

FICTION
The Portage to San Cristobal of A. H.- George Steiner
B-ABEL - Jeremy Lane
Lucky Pierre and the Coldwater Flat - Robert Coover
Nostalgia - David Black
Bachelor Life - M.J. Fitzgerald
Sweet Truth - Walter Abish
Letters from LETTERS - John Barth

ESSAYS & MEMOIR
A Preface to A.H. - Tony Tanner
Science Fiction to Superfiction - Jerome Klinkowitz & Thomas Remington
Language of Detective Fiction: Fiction of Detective Language - D. A. Miller
City of Dis: The Fiction of Don DeLillo - Norman Bryson
The Weightless Characters of William Styron- Robert Boyers
Prose Feature: John Barth - Bill Buford & Pete de Bolla
On the Death of Elizabeth Bishop - Don Guttenplan

POETRY
Two Poems - Richard Godden
Four Poems - Peter Robinson
The Wife - David Katz

IN CONVERSATION
John Barth | Interview

title: The Prelude
author: William Wordsworth
description: This book is the first to present Wordsworth's greatest poem in all three of its separate form. It reprints, on facing pages, the version of "The Prelude" was was completed in 1805, together with the much-revised work published after the poet's death in 1850. In addition the editors include the two-part version of the poem, composed 1798-99. Each of these poems has its distinctive qualities and values; to read them together provides an imcomparable chance to observe a great poet composing and recomposing, through a long life, his major work.

title: Battle of the Planets #4: The Creeping Forest/The Earthquake Menace
author: Win Mortimer
description:
The Creeping Forest:
When the island of Malu suddenly breaks off all outside contact G-Force is sent in to see what is happening. When they get there they find that the island (robot forest + human thugs) is forcing the inhabitants to mine diamonds for Zoltar. When G-Force releases the people a giant robot mole is sent after them. While G-Force uses the Phoenix to destroy the mole Zoltar escapes, leaving the diamonds behind.

The Earthquake Menace:
When an earthquake hits California G-Force is sent to investigate. While they are investigating Zoltar breaks into all communications and declares himself Supreme Commander. He threatens to cause a much stronger earthquake and send San Francisco and Los Angeles into the sea unless the earth surrenders. G-Force finds Zoltar's hidden lair and destroys it when the Phoenix transmutes into the Firebird and crashes into it. They think they have killed Zoltar but it is just a Zoltar robot. Of course, the real Zoltar gets away.
orginalTitle: Battle of the Planets #4: The Creeping Forest/The Earthquake Menace

title: Central Problems in Social Theory: Action, structure and contradiction in social analysis
author: Anthony Giddens
description:
In this new and brilliantly organized book of essays, Anthony Giddens discusses three main theoretical traditions in social science that cut across the division between Marxist and non-Marxist sociology: interpretive sociology, functionalism, and structuralism.

Beginning with a critical examination of the importance of structuralism for contemporary sociology, the author develops a comprehensive account of what he calls "the theory of structuration." One of the main themes is that social theory must recognize, as it has not done hitherto, that all social actors are knowledgeable about the social systems they produce and reproduce in their conduct. In order to grasp the significance of this, he argues, we have to reconsider some of the most basic concepts in sociology.

In particular, Giddens argues, it is essential to recognize the significance of time-space relations in social theory. He rejects the distinction between synchrony and diachrony, or statics and dynamics, involved in both structuralism and functionalism, and offers extensive critical commentary on the latter as an approach to sociology.

The book, which can be described as a "non-functionalist manifesto," breaks with the three main theoretical traditions in the social sciences today while retaining the significant contributions each contains. In so doing Giddens discusses a range of fundamental problem areas in the social sciences: power and domination, conflict and contradiction, and social transformation. He concludes with an overall appraisal of the key problems in social theory today.

title: I, etcetera
author: Susan Sontag
description: In eight stories, this singular collection of short fiction written over the course of ten years explores the terrain of modern urban life. In reflective, telegraphic prose, Susan Sontag confronts the reader with exposed workings of an impassioned intellect in narratives seamed with many of the themes of her essaysâ€”the nature of knowing, our relationship with the past, and the future in an alienated present.

title: Battle of the Planets #3: Solar Blockade/The Lake Monster!
author: Win Mortimer
description:
Solar Blockade: 
Zoltar launches a deflector lens above the planet earth to block out the sun's power and provide cover for a massive invasion of Earth. G-Force transmutes the Phoenix into the firebird and knocks out the deflector lens. The Inter-Galactic Defense System is then able to rout the invasion but Zoltar manages to escape.

The Lake Monster!:
While vacationing Tiny and Keyop encounter a lake monster at Lake Wannoke. The rest of G-Force are recalled from vacation and go to investigate the monster. While they are on their way Keyop goes investigating alone and is kidnapped by Zoltar's thugs. When Zoltar sends the lake monster (which happens to be a robot) after the rest of G-Force Keyop sabotages the controls. Zoltar ties up Keyop and the rest of G-Force are forced to let Zoltar escape while rescuing him.
orginalTitle: Battle of the Planets #3: Solar Blockade/The Lake Monster!

title: Genesis of a Music
author: Harry Partch
description: Among the few truly experimental composers in our cultural history, Harry Partch's life (1901-1974) and music embody most completely the quintessential American rootlessness, isolation, pre-civilized cult of experience, and dichotomy of practical invention and transcendental visions. Having lived mostly in the remote deserts of Arizona and New Mexico with no access to formal training, Partch naturally created theatrical ritualistic works incorporating Indian chants, Japanese kabuki and Noh, Polynesian microtones, Balinese gamelan, Greek tragedy, dance, mime, and sardonic commentary on Hollywood and commercial pop music of modern civilization. First published in 1949, Genesis of a Music is the manifesto of Partch's radical compositional practice and instruments (which owe nothing to the 300-year-old European tradition of Western music.) He contrasts Abstract and Corporeal music, proclaiming the latter as the vital, emotionally tactile form derived from the spoken word (like Greek, Chinese, Arabic, and Indian musics) and surveys the history of world music at length from this perspective. Parts II, III, and IV explain Partch's theories of scales, intonation, and instrument construction with copious acoustical and mathematical documentation. Anyone with a musically creative attitude, whether or not familiar with traditional music theory, will find this book revelatory.

title: Battle of the Planets #2: Ice Creature/The Flaming Menace
author: Win Mortimer
description:
Contains: 
Ice Creature - Dr. Conrad comes upon two men frozen in the ice. They were placed there by Zoltar to sabotage earth's polar security base after they are unfrozen. While G-Force is fighting them Zoltar attacks in a giant snowman robot. The robot is defeated when the Phoenix transmutes into the Firebird and melts the controls but Zoltar gets away.

The Flaming Menace - When a giant torch creature attacks a small village in India G-Force comes to their rescue, however, the creature just absorbs their ammunition. Since weapons can't harm the creature they follow it to find it's weakness. While searching the mountain where it hides Princess is kidnapped and G-Force finds out that Zoltar is behind the creature. After they rescue Princess they perform Operation Whirlwind and cause an avalanche of snow and ice that defeats the creature.

title: Turner's Picturesque Views in England and Wales 1825-1838
author: Eric Shanes
description:
`Picturesque Views in England and Wales' was a major undertaking on the part of J. M.W. Turner, who originally agreed to produce over 100 watercolours, and Charles Heath, who was to have them engraved. It was an ambitious series for which Turner created some of his finest watercolours. In the event 96 of them were engraved before the venture came to an end in 1838. The watercolours were subsequently dispersed into public and private collections, and the majority have not been exhibited since Turner's lifetime. Turner's Picturesque Views in England and Wales brings the series together for the first time in nearly 150 years. All the available watercolours are reproduced, and the few that have been destroyed, or are untraceable, are represented by engravings. Ruskin referred to these pictures as representing Turner's 'central powers and dominant feelings ...towards his native country' More recently, Martin Hardie called them 'magical renderings of colour and atmosphere They include magnificent landscape and maritime scenes, and provide abundant evidence of Turner's gift for composition and his subtle treatment of the human figure. Taken as a whole, the series not only demonstrates his astonishing versatility, but also offers an acutely perceptive portrayal of his age. 

Eric Shanes discusses how the series came about and also analyses the form and content of the watercolours, paying special attention to their symbolism. 

In his introduction Andrew Wilton looks at the evolution of the topographical watercolour in England and examines Turner's unique contribution to the genre in the context of his general development as an artist.

title: Soul Catcher
author: Frank Herbert
description:
Soul Catcher (1972) is a novel by the science fiction writer Frank Herbert. Soul Catcher is about a Native American who kidnaps a young white boy and their journey together. It is a story of vengeance and sacrifice. In the conflicted anti-hero, one may see many truths to the feelings harbored by those who were conquered.
Many Native American myths are touched upon; e.g. that the bee does not haphazardly sting its victim, rather it chooses that person. The book is committed to seeing the sacrifice through and the â€œlambâ€ must be an innocent to represent the many Native American innocents slaughtered. Therein lies the conflict with our tragic hero, that he may actually have found respect for his young white hostage, yet he knows what it is that he must do for his people.

title: Workbook of Cuneiform Signs (AIDS and Research Tools in Ancient Near Eastern Studies)
author: Daniel C. Snell
description: This cuneifrom workbook gives a course of programmed instruction teaching the 110 most frequently used signs. It teaches the standard Neo-Assyrian sign forms and gives the student practice both in passive and active recognition of the signs. The signs are divided into eight sections, and each section ends with a quiz reviewing all signs presented. The book is designed for home study by students in beginning Akkadian classes and provides a practical introduction to the cuneiform writing system.

title: Nail Down the Stars
author: John Morressy
description:
STARFARER AND SKILLMAN, 
Jolon Gallmor has been on the run since his tenth birthday. Among the diverse races and worlds of the galaxy so vividly described in STARBRAT, Jolon's skills as playwright, actor and bard are his passport to privilege and acclaim, all too often to peril and banishment. With each new planet he reaches, Jolon finds himself taking on a new role, hiding his past and keeping one step ahead of the catastrophe which threatens him. 
TROOPER OF THE STERNVEREIN, 
Thief, slave and fugitive, Jolon the peaceable battles his way around the universe, until as Alladale Anthem-maker he defeats an army and wins a world without spilling a drop of blood
quotes: These are books, Lon.' (...) 'Back on Old Earth, even in the Bloody Centuries, it was not uncommon for people to have this many books in their homes. Some people had enough to fill a whole shelf,' Prospero said, his voice hushed with wonder. 'Anyone who had that many was called a librarian'.

title: Anastasia Krupnik
author: Lois Lowry
description: To Anastasia Krupnik, being ten is very confusing. For one thing, she has this awful teacher who can't understand why Anastasia doesn't capitalize or punctuate her poems. Then, there's Washburn Cummings, a very interesting sixth-grade boy who doesn't even know she is alive. Even her parents have become difficult. They insist she visit her 92-year-old grandmother who can never remember Anastasia's name. On top of that, they're going to have a baby -- at their age! It's enough to make a kid want to do something terrible. Anastasia knows that if she didn't have her secret green notebook to write in, she would never make it to her eleventh birthday.

title: Makramy
author: Jadwiga Turska

title: Third World War: August 1985, The
author: John Barraclough
description:
Armageddon is announced...

SHAPE Brussels 4 August 1985
Warsaw Pact Attacks Allied Command Europe STOP First light undercover and parachute operations followed by massive armoured assault along entire front STOP Heavy fighting in Central Europe STOP Allies under severe pressure STOP Soviets claim action QUOTE purely defensive UNQUOTE STOP Situation confused STOP MFL


How, why, when and where would WWIII be fought? General Sir John Hackett - who, in the course of his long and distinguished military careet, served as Deputy Chief of the General Staff and commanded the Northern Army Group in NATO as C-in-C of the British Army of the Rhine - has constructed a gripping and astonishing narrative, presented as though written shortly after the war's end. The result is an outstanding book of compelling fascination and readability - and of the utmost seriousness and relevance to today's high-tension world.


Oprawa: miÄ™kka
Format: 107x176 mm
Cena: 1,75 GBP / 5,50 AUD / 5,50 NZD / 4,25 CAD / 1,925 IEP

title: Doctor Who and the War Games
author: Malcolm Hulke
description:
Mud, barbed wire, the smell of death.. The year was 1917 and the TARDIS had materialised on the Western Front during the First World War.

Or had it? For very soon the Doctor Found himself pursued by the soldiers of Ancient Rome; and then he and his companions were reliving the American Civil War od 1863. And was this really Earth, or just a mock-up created by the War Lords?

As Doctor Who solves the mystery, he has to admit he is faced with an evil of such magnitude that he cannot combat it on his own â€” he has to call for the help of his own people, the Time Lords,

So, for the first time, it is revealed who is Doctor Who â€” a maverick Time Lord who 'borrowed' the TARDIS without permission. By appealing to the Time Lords he gives away his position in Time and Space. Thus comes about the Trial of Doctor Who...

PokaÅ¼ mimo to

title: Ostatni lot
author: Andrzej R. Janczak
description:
Eugeniusz Horbaczewski urodzil sie 28 IX 1917 r. w Kijowie. Jego rodzicami byli Witold Horbaczewski i Anna z domu Kozlowska. Dziecinstwo i lata mlodziencze spedzil w Brzesciu nad Bugiem, gdzie ukonczyl gimnazjum. w 1939 r. otrzymal promocje na stopien podporucznika w Szkole Podchorazych Lotnictwa w Deblinie.
Jego dalsze koleje losu, to pelna przygod podroz do Francji [przez Rumunie, Jugoslawie, Grecje i Malte], a nastepnie do Anglii. Sluzyl w dywizjonie 303 i innych polskich formacjach lotniczych w Wielkiej Brytanii, a takze w jednostce RAF. Jest jednym z rekordzistow w zestrzeleniu samolotow nieprzyjacielskich - ponad 16. Zginal 18 VIII 1944 r. w bitwie powietrznej nad Velennes [Francja], pilotujac samolot Mustang FB 355. Ekshumowany 3 III 1947 r., pochowany zostal w Creil [kolo Paryza], grob Z.379.

description:
Eugeniusz Horbaczewski urodzil sie 28 IX 1917 r. w Kijowie. Jego rodzicami byli Witold Horbaczewski i Anna z domu Kozlowska. Dziecinstwo i lata mlodziencze spedzil w Brzesciu nad Bugiem, gdzie ukonczyl gimnazjum. w 1939 r. otrzymal promocje na stopien podporucznika w Szkole Podchorazych Lotnictwa w Deblinie.
Jego dalsze koleje losu, to pelna przygod podroz do Francji [przez Rumunie, Jugoslawie, Grecje i Malte], a nastepnie do Anglii. Sluzyl w dywizjonie 303 i innych polskich formacjach lotniczych w Wielkiej Brytanii, a takze w jednostce RAF. Jest jednym z rekordzistow w zestrzeleniu samolotow nieprzyjacielskich - ponad 16. Zginal 18 VIII 1944 r. w bitwie powietrznej nad Velennes [Francja], pilotujac samolot Mustang FB 355. Ekshumowany 3 III 1947 r., pochowany zostal w Creil [kolo Paryza], grob Z.379.

title: The Beckett Trilogy: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable
author: Samuel Beckett
description:
`The trilogy seen as a whole comprises one of the most remarkable, most original and most haunting prose works of the century. It is concerned with the search for identity, for the true self which can rest from self caricature; and as a parallel it is concerned with the true silence which is the end of speech. Molloy, Malone and their final unnamable incarnation are paradigms of humanity in general and of the artist in particular. Beckett has seen the Gorgon's head; but he has not been turned to stone.' 
TIMES LITERARY SUPPLEMENT 

`A trilogy of classic importance... the quintessential Beckett, life scabbily surviving through its memories in a bleak environment. Ends "I can't go on, I'll go on". At first folk-sharp and humorous grotesque fantasy, increasingly self-indulgent, the central horror of lonely death hidden, not explored by clouds of words that represent only desperate attempts at breath. Orwell's How the Poor Die orchestrated by Sterne, Joyce and Celine.' 
PUNCH 

`His obsession is with human decay and death, dissolution and desolation... a time-honoured theme, but Beckett's statement of it is his own, and very potent, conveyed by a powerful imagination.' 
GUARDIAN 

`Samuel Beckett is unmistakably a man of genius.' 
OBSERVER 
Cover illustration by Russell Mills
orginalTitle: The Beckett Trilogy: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable

PokaÅ¼ mimo to

title: Pictures by J. R. R. Tolkien
author: Christopher John Reuel Tolkien
description:
The primary purpose of this book is to collect together all the pictures (paintings, drawings, designs) by J. R. R. Tolkien which were published in a series of six Calendars from 1973 to 1979, with a gap in 1975. 

(...) a collection of all the pictures from the Calendars necessarily constitutes a fairly complete record of my father's published work (since the majority of them first appeared in the Calendars, while the Calendars included almost everything that had been published previously - the chief exception being the illustrations of The Father Christmas Letters). I have therefore more nearly approached completeness by the inclusion of a few things that did not appear in the Calendars: the pen and ink drawing of Hobbiton, the Doors of Durin, Mirkwood, and the tree on the cover of the first paperback edition of Tree and Leaf. The illustrations of The Father Christmas Letters have not been repeated, with the exception of the 1928 picture of the Polar Bear fallen to the foot of the stairs in Father Christmas' house, which was used in the 1979 Calendar.

title: The Beckett Trilogy: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable
author: Samuel Beckett
description:
`The trilogy seen as a whole comprises one of the most remarkable, most original and most haunting prose works of the century. It is concerned with the search for identity, for the true self which can rest from self caricature; and as a parallel it is concerned with the true silence which is the end of speech. Molloy, Malone and their final unnamable incarnation are paradigms of humanity in general and of the artist in particular. Beckett has seen the Gorgon's head; but he has not been turned to stone.' 
TIMES LITERARY SUPPLEMENT 

`A trilogy of classic importance... the quintessential Beckett, life scabbily surviving through its memories in a bleak environment. Ends "I can't go on, I'll go on". At first folk-sharp and humorous grotesque fantasy, increasingly self-indulgent, the central horror of lonely death hidden, not explored by clouds of words that represent only desperate attempts at breath. Orwell's How the Poor Die orchestrated by Sterne, Joyce and Celine.' 
PUNCH 

`His obsession is with human decay and death, dissolution and desolation... a time-honoured theme, but Beckett's statement of it is his own, and very potent, conveyed by a powerful imagination.' 
GUARDIAN 

`Samuel Beckett is unmistakably a man of genius.' 
OBSERVER 
Cover illustration by Russell Mills
